description: From Middle English attenden, atenden, from Old French atendre (“to attend, listen”), from Latin attendere (“to stretch toward, give heed to”), from ad (“to”) + tendere (“to stretch”); see tend and compare attempt.

verbs.description: attend (third-person singular simple present attends, present participle attending, simple past and past participle attended)

entries.meaning: (archaic, transitive) To listen to (something or someone); to pay attention to; regard; heed. [from 15th c.]

examples: 'Now attend to me,' said Painted Jaguar, 'because this is very important.  […]

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To turn one's consideration (to); to deal with (a task, problem, concern etc.), to look after. [from 15th c.]
(transitive, intransitive) To wait upon as a servant etc.; to accompany to assist (someone). [from 15th c.]
examples: Valets attend to their employer's wardrobe.
Servants attend the king day and night.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To be present at (an event or place) in order to take part in some action or proceedings; to regularly go to (an event or place). [from 17th c.]
(intransitive, law) To go to (a place) for some purpose (with at).
To be present with; to accompany; to be united or consequent to.
examples: a measure attended with ill effects

entries.meaning: To wait for; to await; to remain, abide, or be in store for.

description: From Middle English attenden, atenden, from Old English ātendan (“to set on fire, kindle, inflame, trouble, perplex”), equivalent to a- +‎ tend.

verbs.description: attend (third-person singular simple present attends, present participle attending, simple past and past participle attended)
